metadata.title: Mortgage Amortization Calculator (Supports Bi‑Weekly Payments)
metadata.description: Estimate bi‑weekly or other periodic mortgage payments, total interest, and savings versus a monthly schedule. Includes options for extra principal per period and shows total payment counts and interest outcomes. Not a loan offer; see accuracy notes and standards citations.

introduction: This calculator estimates mortgage amortization results for any periodic payment cadence (bi‑weekly, monthly, weekly, etc.). Enter the loan principal, annual interest rate (APR), loan term in years, and number of payments per year — set 26 for standard bi‑weekly. Optionally add a recurring extra principal payment applied each period.

Outputs include the periodic payment, total number of payments, total paid over the life of the loan, total interest paid, and a baseline comparison showing estimated interest if payments were made monthly. Results are estimates only and intended for planning and comparison.
methodology: This tool uses standard amortization mathematics: converting annual APR to a periodic interest rate, computing the fixed periodic payment that amortizes principal over the specified number of periods, and aggregating totals over the term.

When computing a baseline monthly comparison, the same principal, APR, and term are used with 12 payments per year to produce a comparable total interest figure. Extra periodic principal payments are added to each scheduled payment to show their impact on interest and total paid.

Accuracy and numeric stability follow good practice for financial calculators. For edge cases (zero interest, extremely short terms, or very large extra payments) analytic formulas may be mathematically singular; see FAQs and accuracy notes below.
how_is_calculated: 1) Convert APR (%) to periodic rate: periodic_rate = APR/100 ÷ payments_per_year.
3) Scheduled payment (without extra principal) uses the annuity formula: payment = principal × periodic_rate ÷ (1 − (1 + periodic_rate) ^ (−number_of_payments)).

4) If extra principal is specified, it is added to the scheduled payment for the periodic payment shown (this shortens effective payoff but this simple presentation shows totals assuming unchanged schedule length).
5) Total paid = payment_with_extra × number_of_payments. Total interest = total paid − principal.
6) Baseline monthly totals are computed by repeating steps 1–5 with payments_per_year = 12 (no extra principal) for comparison.

faqs.question: Does selecting bi‑weekly automatically reduce my loan term?
faqs.answer: Making payments every two weeks can reduce interest because you make more frequent payments and, if structured as 26 payments per year, you pay the equivalent of one extra monthly payment each year. This calculator shows the interest totals under the chosen cadence and with any extra principal per period, but it assumes a consistent schedule; actual payoff date reduction depends on lender processing and whether payments are applied immediately to principal.

faqs.question: What about zero interest or extremely low interest rates?
faqs.answer: The standard annuity formula becomes ill-conditioned when the periodic interest rate is zero. For APR = 0 the periodic payment is principal ÷ number_of_payments. The calculator may show large relative rounding differences for extremely small rates; treat such results as approximate.

faqs.question: Is this a loan offer or exact amortization schedule?
faqs.answer: No. This is an estimator for planning only. Actual lender schedules, fees, escrow, day‑count conventions, rounding rules, and processing timing affect final paydown and interest. Consult your lender for an exact payoff schedule.

faqs.question: How accurate are the calculations and what standards do you follow?
faqs.answer: Calculations follow standard numerical formulas used in consumer finance. Numerical methods and data handling are informed by best practices and reference standards (see citations). Results are not audited for individual lending programs; always verify with lender statements when making decisions.

faqs.question: Why might results differ from my lender's statement?
faqs.answer: Differences can arise from payment application timing (same‑day vs next business day), lender rounding conventions, additional fees, escrow payments included in scheduled amounts, and whether the lender uses 360‑day vs 365‑day day count. This tool uses a straightforward periodic compounding model for comparison.

glossary.definition: The process of paying off debt over time through regular payments of principal and interest according to a schedule.
Annual interest rate expressed as a percentage. This calculator uses APR to compute the periodic interest rate for each payment period.
The interest rate applied each payment period: APR/100 divided by the number of payments per year.
A payment cadence with 26 payments per year (payment every two weeks). Results depend on whether a lender treats bi‑weekly plans as accelerated payments or simply installments.
An amount paid in addition to the scheduled payment that is applied directly to principal, which can reduce interest and shorten payoff time.
